name: NewYorker
text:
The President’s infection will undoubtedly insure that his bungling of the pandemic—which continues to kill nearly a thousand Americans a day, and to sicken thousands more—remains the overriding story of the campaign.
https://t.co/CevDNzmtZU

name: NewYorker
text: Ethan Hawke says he never looked back after “Before Sunrise.” “I could stop imitating other actors. I guess it’s about breaking the mask we wear for the world and letting as much truth seep out of the cracks as possible.” https://t.co/1Zz3GJukLL

name: NewYorker
text: A new 30-minute documentary profiles the Japanese botanical artist Azuma Makoto, a punk and a poet at heart, whose true subject is the fleeting nature of life. Watch here. https://t.co/r3ylQSxtk1

name: NewYorker
text: Conspiracy theories like QAnon blossom in trying times, but today they are supercharged by the tools of our hyperconnected communities. https://t.co/aZcaDNzBWC

name: NewYorker
text:
The response of Donald Trump’s circle to his infection will reveal whether they are coming to grips with reality, or continuing to flee from it.
https://t.co/j3qDuYbRhJ

name: NewYorker
text: In this moment of exalting uprisings and reëmergent social movements, @KeeangaYamahtta writes, we cannot overlook the disturbing history of the Supreme Court and its regressive role in American society. https://t.co/EUl71gZYxk

name: NewYorker
text: Hervé Guibert's work is a singular contribution to the literature of illness, the testament of a writer bracingly committed to everything that, in Virginia Woolf’s words, “the cautious respectability of health conceals.” https://t.co/Dy5g40ztqN

name: NewYorker
text: Mariah Carey’s new memoir is an incisive, entertaining, and impressively well-written account of her road from poverty and obscurity to superstardom. https://t.co/s9fu4qyXGu

name: NewYorker
text: It is human nature to react to a moral decay by creating new institutions, the plague scholar Gianna Pomata says. Could COVID-19 create an opportunity for profound social change?  https://t.co/mqE0bxmple

name: NewYorker
text: Documents show that Deutsche bank used mirror trades to help major criminal organizations, terrorist groups, and drug cartels launder and transfer a geyser of dirty money. https://t.co/v72OkQ1KKl

name: NewYorker
text: There is disagreement about how accurate the PCR tests for the coronavirus are, but estimates suggest that the false-negative rate could range as high as 30 per cent. https://t.co/pggczuI4ek

name: NewYorker
text: The influenza epidemic, which left more than 675,000 Americans dead, may have contributed to the longing for normalcy that brought Warren G. Harding to the White House. https://t.co/417eHv0GNB

name: NewYorker
text: The newfound interest in Black stories is long overdue, but it will inevitably lead to escalating tensions between the companies profiting from those narratives and the families depicted in them. https://t.co/UCaf9qWlfr

name: NewYorker
text: The nonprofit gallery and studio Creative Growth has responded to the coronavirus pandemic in inventive, nimble, and enlivening ways. https://t.co/BJaSRSyYDg

text: Interactive installations at the @AMNH, which is now open Wednesday through Sunday, teach visitors about the electromagnetic spectrum, purple dye’s connection to snails, and more. https://t.co/oNuZMWYUP9

name: NewYorker
text: Joan Aiken treated her fanciful premises with deadpan seriousness, creating an atmosphere that’s ironic and enchanted all at once. https://t.co/hcLFG92HeB

name: NewYorker
text: .@JaneMayerNYer and @JeffreyToobin discuss Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s legacy, how the fight for her seat will affect the 2020 election, and the key cases that the Court is likely to hear in the coming term. Listen here. https://t.co/X5IqYTCgIY

name: NewYorker
text: .@rizwanahmed discusses his creative process, the feeling of home, and what the coronavirus pandemic is forcing us to reconsider. https://t.co/VvKNsJKtDf

name: NewYorker
text: “From the start of his Presidency, Donald Trump has threatened the health and the security of the United States,” David Remnick writes. “It has now been made clear that Trump’s incompetence, cynicism, and recklessness have threatened his own welfare.” https://t.co/FMtBeGdzwz

name: NewYorker
text:
In their courting of Catholic conservatives, William Barr and his cohort are inviting the kind of government that the Founders drafted a Declaration of Independence and fought a war to reject, @Paul_R_Elie writes. 
https://t.co/EciNpWA2cx

name: NewYorker
text: .@JaneMayerNYer reports that Kimberly Guilfoyle tried to raise hush money to silence a former assistant at Fox News, who alleged sexual harassment against Guilfoyle. https://t.co/p9061DOGN4

name: NewYorker
text: “I just couldn’t sleep,” Max Kennedy, Jr., said, of what he witnessed while working on President Trump’s coronavirus task force. “I was so distressed and disturbed by what I’d seen.” https://t.co/Tc3bmHb1oI

name: NewYorker
text: If Democrats win a majority in the Senate and Joe Biden wins the Presidency after President Trump pushes through a Supreme Court nominee, there are four major possibilities for retribution—which all happen to be good policy as well. https://t.co/444oOJ9teW
